instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.

threads.title: 00165 low 3v42
threads.message:
Board isn't necessarily clean but no liquid contact or relevant visible corrosion. PP3V42 is usually either 1.5V or 2.2V with no correlation to anything I can tell.

Board is on bench and checked with Main flex cable removed also and tried with different DCIN board.

Things I tried: replacing <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>
Pulled <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, SMC. Thoroughly inspected areas with direct pp3V42 connection. NO change in PP3V42 with any of those components removed.

Also get 1.2V on <SIGNAL>PP1V2_VDDC_SMC_S5</SIGNAL>

Replaced L7095 also.

Checked with FLIR also... not seeing anything unusual but suspect this is not major short. I get .313 in diode mode on pp3V42

threads.title: 00165 low 3v42
threads.message:
Remove <CAPACITOR>C7095</CAPACITOR> and test.
Check <RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR>/96 integrity and traces.
Post diode mode to ground at L7095.
Play with Ra/Rb to get correct voltage.

threads.title: 00165 low 3v42
threads.message:
Voltage dropped? to 1.2V with <CAPACITOR>C7095</CAPACITOR> removed but guessing that didn't cause the drop. Regardless, no pp3v42 present still.
Diode at L7095 is .313.
What do you mean Ra/Rb to get correct voltage?

threads.title: 00165 low 3v42
threads.message:
Look at the formula near that area in schematic.
Ra and Rb are clearly marked.
